content.description: Sit Start on a nice big rail feature with massive feet. Kind of a weird pull on and balancey first couple moves. Go up the rails and then continue up and right on the lip before mantleing at the apex. Great warmup, and really challenging with no chalk and sneakers.
content.location: This is the obvious face problem on the backside of the Moonstone.

content.description:
Originally done from a stand-start with the right hand on the face and the left hand on the sharp crystals on the arete. Pull onto the wall and make a few slabby balance moves while utilizing the arete and features found on the face. Continue moving up and rightwards following the slopey arete before reaching a good meathook at the right arete and topping out.

 Doing a squat start down and left incorporates a few extra powerful, technical and friction dependent moves into the stand at a grade or so harder.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads. Maybe a spotter for the top-out.
content.location: This boulder problem is found on the North face of the boulder. It is a right-leaning arete with a large maple tree obstructing the full- sit potential.

content.description: This is a forced line directly up the face between "Moonstone Face" and "Clefable".Begin as for Moonstone Face and establish on the blank face with the huge right foot and a thumb undercling. The aretes are off. Using trickery, climb the face direct to the boulder's apex.
content.protection: pads. careful of the ankle roller rock.

content.description: A fun boulder problem from a sit-start at the base of a vertical arete. Grab a very small left-hand crimp and a low hold on the arete for the right. Figure out how to pull on and surge up to a small index finger side-pinch. Once here figure out where to move your feet and how to balance your way up to improving holds before topping out in easier terrain.
content.location: This problem follows the vertical arete found on the right side of the North face.

content.description: Stand start at the right arete with a few small crimp options for the left hand, and the other hand on the arete. Pull onto the wall and make a few fun technical moves up to improving holds before grabbing slopers and meathooks at the lip of the boulder and topping out.
content.location: This is the original stand start of the right arete found on the North face of The Moonstone.

content.description: Sit start under the short overhang. Pull onto the wall and mantle the lip feature.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads. there is a rock under you.

content.description:
Sit start on some rail features to the right of the tree. Pull on to the wall and make a few moves up before reaching over the angle change and holding some slopey holds on the slab. From here figure out how to balance your way onto the low angle slab before topping out in easier terrain. 

 Hint: There is a large hold behind the tree that looks useful, but wasn't needed or used for the problem.
content.location: This problem is found on the West face of the boulder, just right of a large tree growing adjacent to the boulder.

content.description: Sit Start with Left hand on a jug undercling/sidepull and Right hand on the arete. Using a big right foot, pull on and get established on the face and arete. Pull a cruxy move getting from slopers on the arete to the apex of the boulder and then mantle.
content.location: To the right of "Moonstone Face." This climbs the right arete on the backside of the boulder, the arete closest to the massive tree/downclimb.

content.description:
This is a pyramid-shaped boulder at the base of a talus covered hillside. The Moonstone has a flat landing and hosts a few fun problems to add to the warm-up circuit. The North-West face holds a few harder problems, while the South-East face has a few slightly easier ones. 

  This boulder is shaded by a forest in summer-time but is fairly exposed during the other three seasons due to the number of deciduous trees in the area. Further East from this boulder is a large vernal pool/ wetland that is home to thousands of mosquito-larvae which make the change in the summer and fall months in an attempt to repel visitors from this area. Citronella bracelets, candles and Deet tend to work fairly well in aiding the adventurer.
